summary: The text discusses the opening and closing of the gates of Janus during the reigns of Augustus and Vespasian. Augustus opened Janus, and it remained open until the reign of Vespasian, reflecting a period of expansion and conflict. After the destruction of Jerusalem and the defeat of the Jews, Titus closed the gates as a symbolic act ordered by divine judgment as vengeance for the blood of Jesus Christ. Although open during the later days of Caesar, there were no significant wars. This period is associated with a time of peace during which Jesus Christ, in the Gospels, speaks about future turmoil including wars, famines, and earthquakes as signs of the beginning of sorrows.
